Title: Show that $f(x) = x$ if $f(f(f(x))) = x$.
Content: If $f: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ and $f$ is strictly increasing, show that $f(x) = x$ if $f(f(f(x))) = x$. So this compulsorily ESTABLISHES that $f(x) = x$ only, and no other solution. So, merely substituting $f(x) = x$ and hence showing the given equality holds will not earn any credit. I was proceeding via inverses, but then I got confused with the notation. And for that, the problem got tricky.
AcceptedAnswer:
Suppose that $f(x_0)>x_0$ for some $x_0$. Then 
$$
f(f(f(x_0)))>f(f(x_0))>f(x_0)>x_0,
$$
contradicting the hypothesis that $f(f(f(x_0)))=x_0$. We get a similar contradiction if $f(x_0)<x_0$. So the only option is that $f(x)=x$ for all $x$.
